In addition to the points in system 1 listed in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a>, the model-independent reconstruction and Grale use the positions of up to five additional identifiable bright spots in all images of system 1 listed in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T2\">Table 2</a>. These points were determined by eye of the HST ACS/WFC image in the F475W band (PI:Ford 2004<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FN1\">1</a></sup> ), in which these resolved features are most prominent.</p>\n<a name=\"T1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1</span></a>\n<p>Systems of multiple images employed in the model-based lens reconstructions.</p>\n</div></div>\n<a name=\"T2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/T2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 2</span></a>\n<p>Positions of six bright spots, referred to as reference points (RP), identifiable in each of the five images (I) of system 1\nfrom <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a>.</p>\n</div></div>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S3\"></a>3 Model-independent lens reconstruction</h2>\n<p>In <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R23\">Tessore (2017)</a>, it was shown how properties of strong gravitational lenses can be recovered in a model-independent fashion from the mapping of multiple images onto one another. Given <i>n</i> multiple images, the <i>image maps</i> <i>&#966;</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> are functions that map the arbitrarily chosen reference image 1 onto the multiple image <i>i</i> = 2, &#8230;, <i>n</i>. The Jacobian matrix of the image map <i>&#966;</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> is the <i>relative magnification matrix</i> <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq4.png\"></span> between images 1 and <i>i</i>, where A is the usual magnification matrix,\n<a name=\"FD1\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq5.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(1)</span></span></p>\n<p>in terms of the convergence <i>&#954;</i> and the two components of the reduced shear <i>g</i>\n<a name=\"FD2\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq6.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(2)</span></span></p>\n<p>with <i>&#947;</i><sub><i>i</i>,1</sub> and <i>&#947;</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub> denoting the shear components for each image <i>i</i>, as defined in the usual notation by <a name=\"InR22\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R22\">Schneider et al. (1992)</a> with respect to the RA/Dec coordinate system.</p>\n<p>Explicitly writing out the entries of T<sub><i>i</i></sub>, <i>i</i> = 2, &#8230;, <i>n</i>,\n<a name=\"FD3\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq7.png\"></span></p>\n<p>the reduced shears <i>g</i><sub>1,<i>j</i></sub> and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,<i>j</i></sub>, <i>j</i> = 1, 2, are generally recoverable, while the convergences <i>&#954;</i><sub>1</sub> and <i>&#954;</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> only appear in the form of a <i>convergence ratio</i>,\n<a name=\"FD4\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq8.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(7)</span></span></p>\n<p>that scales all components of T<sub><i>i</i></sub> equally. Therefore, neither <i>&#954;</i><sub>1</sub> nor <i>&#954;</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> can be recovered individually (this is also implied by the mass sheet degeneracy), and only the convergence ratios and reduced shears <i>g</i><sub>1,1</sub>, <i>g</i><sub>1,2</sub>, <i>f</i><sub>2</sub>, <i>g</i><sub>2,1</sub>, <i>g</i><sub>2,2</sub>, &#8230; are observable properties of strong gravitational lenses at first order in the image mapping and hence second order in the deflection potential.</p>\n<p>To reconstruct the values of <i>f</i> and <i>g</i> from a given relative magnification matrix T, it is useful to construct combinations of the entries (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD3\">3</a>)&#8211;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD3\">6</a>),\n<a name=\"FD5\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq9.png\"></span></p>\n<p>We note that <i>c</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> and <i>d</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> are the curl and divergence of the image map, respectively. When at least three images 1, <i>i</i>, <i>j</i> are observed, the system of Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD5\">8</a>)&#8211;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD5\">11</a>) can be solved for the reduced shear of the reference image,\n<a name=\"FD6\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq10.png\"></span></p>\n<p>as well as the convergence ratio and shear of multiple image <i>i</i>,\n<a name=\"FD7\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq11.png\"></span></p>\n<p>where det(T<sub><i>i</i></sub>) is the determinant. The same expressions hold for multiple image <i>j</i>.</p>\n<p>With\n<a name=\"FD8\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq12.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(17)</span></span></p>\n<p>we relate the determinant of the transformation matrix to the magnification ratio between image <i>i</i>, <i>&#956;</i><sub><i>i</i></sub>, and image 1, <i>&#956;</i><sub>1</sub>, which yields the relative parities between those images and can be compared to the respective measured flux ratios. Using Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD3\">3</a>) to (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD3\">6</a>), the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq13.png\"></span> can be expressed in terms of the <i>f</i><sub><i>i</i></sub>, <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,1</sub>, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub>, so that they do not yield additional information.</p>\n<p>By constructing the image maps <i>&#966;</i><sub><i>i</i></sub>, <i>i</i> = 2, &#8230;, <i>n</i>, from observations and evaluating their Jacobian matrices, it is possible to measure the relative magnification matrix T<sub><i>i</i></sub> directly from data. This in turn makes it possible to reconstruct the magnification ratios (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD8\">17</a>), convergence ratios (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD7\">14</a>), and reduced shears (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD7\">15</a>)&#8211;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD7\">16</a>) &#8211; that is, the observable properties &#8211; of the gravitational lens in a completely model-independent manner.</p>\n<p>Equations (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD2\">2</a>), (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD4\">7</a>), and (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD8\">17</a>) define lens properties that can also be extracted from model-based convergence and shear maps and thus be compared between all three lens reconstruction methods.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S4\"></a>3.1 Linear image mapping by point matching</h3>\n<p>We assume that an observer has found a family of <i>m</i> points, also referred to as reference points in the following, individually labelled from 1 to <i>m</i>, that reliably show the same features across all multiple images. In addition, we require that convergence and shear do not vary significantly over the area covered by the family of points in each multiple image. Then, it is possible to approximate the image maps as linear transformations of conjugate points between the multiple images.</p>\n<p>Let <b><i>x</i></b><sub><i>ij</i></sub> denote the point with index <i>j</i> = 1, &#8230;, <i>m</i> in multiple image <i>i</i> = 2, &#8230;, <i>n</i>, and <b><i>x</i></b><sub>1<i>j</i></sub> the corresponding point in the reference image 1. If the assumption of linearity holds, the image mapping is described by a matrix, which in this case is the relative magnification matrix T<sub><i>i</i></sub>. Mapping the observed points <b><i>x</i></b><sub>11</sub>, <b><i>x</i></b><sub>12</sub>, &#8230; from reference image 1 to multiple image <i>i</i> should recover the observed points <b><i>x</i></b><sub><i>ij</i></sub>,\n<a name=\"FD9\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq14.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(18)</span></span></p>\n<p>where <b><i>&#958;</i></b><sub><i>i</i></sub>, <b><i>&#958;</i></b><sub>1</sub> are <i>anchor points</i> for the affine transformation between multiple images 1 and <i>i</i>. Lens reconstruction by point matching amounts to finding a relative magnification matrix T<sub><i>i</i></sub> that solves this equation for all points <i>j</i> in a given image <i>i</i>.</p>\n<p>As the reconstructed T<sub><i>i</i></sub> is the solution of the linearised mapping over the entire area covered by the family of points in a multiple image, it is not necessarily the same as the relative magnification matrix that would be obtained from a fully non-linear image map at the points <b><i>&#958;</i></b><sub><i>i</i></sub> and <b><i>&#958;</i></b><sub>1</sub>. The anchor point <b><i>&#958;</i></b><sub>1</sub> of the reference image is arbitrary, since it can be absorbed into the left-hand side of Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD9\">18</a>). However, it makes sense to pick <b><i>&#958;</i></b><sub>1</sub> within the observed image, for example as the centroid of the points <b><i>x</i></b><sub>1<i>j</i></sub>. The locations of the remaining anchor points <b><i>&#958;</i></b><sub>2</sub>, <b><i>&#958;</i></b><sub>3</sub>, &#8230;, which are additional free parameters of the reconstruction, can then be understood as the images of <b><i>&#958;</i></b><sub>1</sub> under the linearised image mapping.</p>\n<p>In observations, the images <b><i>x</i></b><sub><i>ij</i></sub> of the reference points <b><i>x</i></b><sub>1<i>j</i></sub> will be localised with some level of uncertainty. The difference between an observed position <b><i>x</i></b><sub><i>ij</i></sub> and the prediction (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD9\">18</a>) can be modelled as a bivariate normal random variable,\n<a name=\"FD10\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq15.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(19)</span></span></p>\n<p>where the uncertainty in the observed position <b><i>x</i></b><sub><i>ij</i></sub> is described by a covariance matrix &#931;<sub><i>ij</i></sub>. No uncertainty is associated with the reference points <b><i>x</i></b><sub>1<i>j</i></sub>, which are fixed by the observer. For given relative magnification matrices T<sub><i>i</i></sub>, the quality of the reconstruction is then quantified by the <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup>-value,\n<a name=\"FD11\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq16.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(20)</span></span></p>\n<p>where the sum extends over <i>n</i> &#8722; 1 multiple images of the reference image 1 and their <i>m</i> observed points. Minimising the <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup> -term (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD11\">20</a>) returns best-fit values for the relative magnification matrices T<sub><i>i</i></sub> and anchor points <b><i>&#958;</i></b><sub><i>i</i></sub>, which are the degrees of freedom of the reconstruction. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F1\">Figure 1</a> visualises the point matching using the six reference points in system 1 of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T2\">Table 2</a> as example (left) and it shows a schematic of how the linear transformation is derived from the magnification matrices of two images with two reference points and one anchor point in each image (right).</p>\n<a name=\"F1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1</span></a>\n<p>CL0024 with detailed pictures of the five multiple images of system 1 (<i>left</i>). The user-defined reference points in\nthe reference image 1 are marked by red circles, while the red-encircled regions in the remaining images denote 95%\nconfidence bounds of the locations of the transformed reference points by the best-fit linear transformations. (Image\ncredits: NASA, ESA, M. J. Jee (Johns Hopkins University)). Also shown is a diagram of the principle of extracting local\nlens properties from the linear transformation between multiple images from the same source (<i>right</i>).</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S5\"></a>3.2 Parametrisation of the matrices</h3>\n<p>When more than three multiple images of a source are observed, the system of constraints for the convergence ratios and reduced shears is overdetermined, since the <i>n</i> &#8722; 1 relative magnification matrices have 4<i>n</i> &#8722; 4 coefficients, for 3<i>n</i> &#8722; 1 lens quantities (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R23\">Tessore 2017</a>). In this case, the relative magnification matrices T<sub><i>i</i></sub> cannot directly be used as the parameters of the reconstruction: Each pair <i>i</i>, <i>j</i> of images could yield a different reduced shear over the reference image (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD6\">12</a>)&#8211;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD6\">13</a>), leading to an inconsistent reconstruction.</p>\n<p>To circumvent the problem, a suitable parametrisation of the matrices T<sub><i>i</i></sub> can be adopted. A natural choice are the convergence ratio <i>f</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> and reduced shear components <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,1</sub>, <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub>, so that the relative magnification matrices are given by expressions (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD3\">3</a>)&#8211;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD3\">6</a>). In practice, this leads to a numerically difficult reconstruction: Due to the non-linear form of the expressions, the parameters <i>f</i><sub><i>i</i></sub>, <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,1</sub>, <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub> are strongly correlated, which makes the exploration of the parameter space difficult with simple numerical methods.</p>\n<p>A more practical parametrisation keeps the optimisation problem as nearly linear as possible. This can be achieved by noting that for every relative magnification matrix T<sub><i>i</i></sub>, there exists a relation between the <i>a</i><sub><i>i</i></sub>, <i>b</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> and <i>c</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> coefficients (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD5\">8</a>)&#8211;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD5\">10</a>) and the reduced shear <i>g</i><sub>1,1</sub>, <i>g</i><sub>1,2</sub> over the reference image,\n<a name=\"FD12\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq17.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(21)</span></span></p>\n<p>Hence it is possible to use the coefficients <i>a</i><sub><i>i</i></sub>, <i>b</i><sub><i>i</i></sub>, <i>d</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> for multiple images <i>i</i> = 2, &#8230;, <i>n</i>, together with the reduced shear <i>g</i><sub>1,1</sub>, <i>g</i><sub>1,2</sub> over the reference image as the parameters of the reconstruction and write the relative magnification matrices as\n<a name=\"FD13\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq18.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(22)</span></span></p>\n<p>where the coefficient <i>c</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> must be computed from the relation in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD12\">21</a>). With this parametrisation, the reconstruction remains consistent and, at the same time, easy to handle with standard numerical methods.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S6\"></a>3.3 Implementation</h3>\n<p>An implementation of the image mapping technique presented here is publicly available<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FN2\">2</a></sup> . The ptmatch routine will take a list of reference points with optional uncertainties and perform the point matching described above. Also provided are converters between relative magnification matrices and lens quantities, as well as utilities for producing mapped images and a source reconstruction.</p>\n<p>The C implementation of the MPFIT routine <a name=\"InR16\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R16\">Markwardt (2009)</a> is used to minimise the <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup> - term (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD11\">20</a>) and returns the best-fit values for the reduced shear <i>g</i><sub>1,1</sub>, <i>g</i><sub>1,2</sub> of the reference image, the coefficients <i>a</i><sub><i>i</i></sub>, <i>b</i><sub><i>i</i></sub>, <i>d</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> of the relative magnification matrices, and the components <i>&#958;</i><sub><i>i</i>,1</sub>, <i>&#958;</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub> of the anchor points, resulting in a total number of 5<i>n</i> &#8722; 3 parameters. The number of constraints from <i>m</i> points in <i>n</i> &#8722; 1 multiple images is 2 <i>m</i> (<i>n</i> &#8722; 1). Hence a minimum of three points in three images is necessary, in which case the system is solvable, as expected (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R23\">Tessore 2017</a>).</p>\n<p>MPFIT requires the <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup>-term (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD11\">20</a>) to be the sum of squares of uncorrelated random deviates <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq19.png\"></span> of unit variance,\n<a name=\"FD14\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq20.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(23)</span></span></p>\n<p>To bring the difference terms (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD10\">19</a>) into the required form, a whitening transform W<sub><i>ij</i></sub> with <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq21.png\"></span> is applied to the random variables,\n<a name=\"FD15\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq22.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(24)</span></span></p>\n<p>so that the two components of the result are uncorrelated with unit variance. For a covariance matrix &#931; with variances <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq23.png\"></span>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq24.png\"></span> and correlation coefficient <i>&#961;</i>, a possible whitening transform is given by the Cholesky decomposition of the inverse matrix &#931;<sup>&#8722;1</sup>,\n<a name=\"FD16\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq25.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(25)</span></span></p>\n<p>It is clear that the <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup>-value of the transformed variables,\n<a name=\"FD17\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq26.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(26)</span></span></p>\n<p>is formally the same as the original term (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD11\">20</a>), and at the same time of the required form (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD14\">23</a>) for MPFIT.</p>\n<p>Besides the best-fit values, MPFIT also allows us to estimate the covariance matrix of the parameters near the minimum by numerical differentiation<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FN3\">3</a></sup>. Both results can be used together to sample the parameter space using importance sampling from a normal distribution with the estimated covariance matrix and centred on the maximum-likelihood parameters. This process yields a full likelihood distribution and allows for the estimation of robust confidence bounds for the reconstructed lens quantities. As examples, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F2\">Figs. 2</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F3\">3</a> show these likelihood distributions for the two model-independent reconstructions of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq27.png\"></span>, and <i>g</i> using all six and the last four reference points of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T2\">Table 2</a>, respectively.</p>\n<a name=\"F2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2</span></a>\n<p>Likelihood distributions of the model-independently determined <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq65.png\"></span>,\n<i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,1</sub>,\nand <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub>,\n<i>i</i> = 1, ..., 5\nusing all six reference points of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T2\">Table 2</a>. Dark-grey shaded areas mark the region between the 16th and\n84th percentiles.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div>\n<a name=\"F3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3</span></a>\n<p>As in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F2\">Fig. 2</a> but using the last four reference points of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T2\">Table 2</a>. Dark-grey shaded\nareas mark the region between the 16th and 84th percentiles.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S7\"></a>3.4 Testing and application to CL0024</h3>\n<p>For lensing by a simulated singular isothermal, elliptical lens, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R25\">Wagner &amp; Tessore (2018)</a> showed that this approach becomes inaccurate when the reference points are spread over distances of 10% of the distance between the closest multiple images. Then, the prerequisite that convergence and shear variations over the image areas are negligible breaks down. Comparing the spread of the six reference points for the first image around their centre, which is approximately 1<sup>&#8243;</sup>, with the distance of this image to the second one, which is approximately 10<sup>&#8243;</sup>, we observe that this limit may be reached for CL0024.</p>\n<p>Therefore, we perform one reconstruction of the local lens properties using all six reference points in each image and compare it to the results obtained by discarding the first two reference points in each image. While the former reconstruction may become inaccurate due to the large area covered by the reference points, we reduce the area over which the reference points are spread in the latter reconstruction (see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F1\">Fig. 1</a> left).</p>\n<p>As the approach assumes that variations of convergence and shear are negligible over the area covered by the reference points, all image points in the convex hull of the reference points are assigned the same <i>f</i>-, <i>g</i>-, and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq28.png\"></span>-values determined by the linear transformation between the multiple images.</p>\n<p>Using all six reference points for all five images listed in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T2\">Table 2</a>, we obtain the mean <i>f</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> -, <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,1</sub> -, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub> -values and their standard deviations from 10 000 samples as shown in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T5\">Table 5</a> in the ninth column block. Discarding the first two reference points and repeating the evaluation for another 10 000 samples, the results are listed in the tenth column block of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T5\">Table 5</a>. The likelihood distributions with the median values and the confidence levels from the 16th and 84th percentile determined from the 10 000 samples are shown in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F2\">Figs. 2</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F3\">3</a>.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S8\"></a>4 Lens models for CL0024</h2>\n<p>To investigate the influence of the number of strong lensing constraints on the local magnification ratios, ratios of convergences, and reduced shear values (Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD4\">7</a>) to (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD8\">17</a>)) for the parametric and non-parametric lens modelling methods, we generate lens models\n<ul class=\"dash\">\n<li>\n<p>using all six systems of multiple images (as selected according to Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S10\">4.1.1</a>) with Grale and Lenstool;</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n<p>using only the constraints from system 1 of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a> with Grale and Lenstool; and</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n<p>using the positions of all six resolved features of system 1 as constraints<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FN4\">4</a></sup>\nwith Grale.</p>\n</li>\n</ul></p>\n<p>For the last configuration of the list, we generate one Grale model with small-scale mass corrections and one without, in order to also investigate possible overfitting to the multiple images at the cost of unrealistic mass distributions, as found in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R20\">Ponente &amp; Diego (2011)</a> for another non-parametric lens modelling approach.</p>\n<p>As cosmological parameters, both lens modelling methods use\n<a name=\"FD18\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq29.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(27)</span></span></p>\n<p>for the Hubble constant, the matter, and dark energy density parameters, respectively, in agreement with the Planck measurements (<a name=\"InR18\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R18\">Planck Collaboration XIII 2016</a>).</p>\n<p>To ensure that all models have the least human-induced bias possible, the parametric and non-parametric models are simultaneously and independently generated by two of the authors based on the multiple image positions determined by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R27\">Zitrin et al. (2009)</a> and the positions of the six resolved features in system 1 determined by the third author prior to modelling.</p>\n<p>The quality of the lens models can be compared by the root-mean-square deviations (RMSI) between the model-generated images and the observed ones, which are calculated in the same way for both lens model approaches (see Sects. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S9\">4.1</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S13\">4.2</a>).</p>\n<p>From the analytical models, we produce convergence and shear maps at the resolution of 0.05<sup>&#8243;</sup> per pixel and determine the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq30.png\"></span>-, <i>f</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> -, <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,1</sub> -, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub> -values, <i>i</i> = 1, ..., 5, and their confidence bounds at the positions of system 1 listed in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a> to compare these local lens properties for all three lens description approaches in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S18\">5</a>.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S9\"></a>4.1 Parametric reconstruction by Lenstool</h3>\n<p>Lenstool is a software package that models gravitational lenses as a superposition of smooth, analytical, large-scale dark matter halo profiles of a specific type previously selected by the user and takes into account the luminous cluster member galaxies with their smaller-scale dark matter halos<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FN5\">5</a></sup>. The parameters of the latter are determined as an ensemble with the same mass profile from the light-traces-mass assumption and the Tully&#8211;Fisher and Faber&#8211;Jackson scaling relations.</p>\n<p>As further detailed in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R11\">Jullo et al. (2007)</a>, the optimum lens model for given ranges of parameter values of the predefined dark matter halo profiles, the catalogue of the brightest member galaxies, and the constraints from the systems of multiple images is obtained by source plane optimisation or image plane optimisation.</p>\n<p>For all Lenstool lens models, we choose the pseudo-isothermal mass distribution (PIEMD) as the analytic large-scale dark matter halo profile, which is also used for the latest Lenstool reconstruction of CL0024 employing strong lensing constraints performed by Richard et al. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R21\">2011</a>; see references therein). As catalogue of brightest member galaxies, we use the one from the Lenstool homepage<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FN6\">6</a></sup> , also employed in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R21\">Richard et al. (2011)</a>.</p>\n<p>We assess the quality of our Lenstool models by three goodness-of-fit estimators, as described in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R11\">Jullo et al. (2007)</a>: the RMSI between the model-generated multiple images and the observed ones, the logarithm of the evidence for that model, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq31.png\"></span>, and its <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup>-value.</p>\n<p>The parameters of the optimum lens model and their confidence bounds are determined by a Bayesian Markov-Chain-Monte-Carlo (MCMC) approach, as detailed in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R11\">Jullo et al. (2007)</a>. In the same manner, the redshifts for all systems without a spectroscopic redshift are predicted, to be compared with the measured photometric ones and the ones from the model by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R27\">Zitrin et al. (2009)</a>.</p>\n<p>To obtain magnification ratios, ratios of convergences, and reduced shear values at the positions of system 1 listed in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a> according to Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD4\">7</a>) to (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD8\">17</a>) with confidence bounds, we generate 30 convergence and shear maps and use the average of the retrieved values and their standard deviations for the comparison in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S18\">5</a>.</p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S10\"></a>4.1.1 Selection of multiple-image systems and number of dark matter halos</h4>\n<p>We generate Lenstool models with one, two, and three PIEMD large-scale dark matter halos employing all multiple-image systems of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R27\">Zitrin et al. (2009)</a> and the catalogue of the 85 brightest member galaxies from the Lenstool homepage. Since these models are only used for selection purposes, we optimise them using the fast source plane optimisation. Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#APP1\">A</a> shows the configuration file for one PIEMD dark matter halo. In agreement with <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R21\">Richard et al. (2011)</a>, we find that the minimal most likely number of dark matter halos is two, taking into account the uncertainty limits of the optimisation procedure. Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#APP3\">C</a> shows the critical curves and caustics of the three models, their goodness-of-fit measures, and the positions of all multiple images on the HST ACS/WFC image in the F475W band (PI:Ford 2004).</p>\n<p>With the same three lens models, we select the set of multiple image systems to generate the best-fit Lenstool model by considering the RMSI for all individual multiple image systems and keep the multiple image systems with the lowest RMSI that sample the vicinity of system 1. Further details about the selection process leading to the set of employed multiple image systems in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a> can be found in Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#APP3\">C</a>.</p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S11\"></a>4.1.2 Reconstruction with six multiple image systems</h4>\n<p>The best-fit Lenstool model is thus calculated using the multiple images of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a>, two PIEMD large-scale dark matter halo profiles, and the catalogue of the 85 brightest member galaxies. Since the model-independent approach employs image plane observables to retrieve local lens properties at the position of the multiple images, we optimise this model in the image plane. Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#APP2\">B</a> shows the configuration file to obtain this model.</p>\n<p>Lenstool also solves for the unknown redshifts of the five multiple image systems that have not been analysed spectroscopically. We obtain the following mean values and standard deviations from the implemented MCMC sampling.\n<a name=\"FD19\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq32.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(28)</span></span></p>\n<p>Comparing these results to those obtained by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R27\">Zitrin et al. (2009)</a> in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a>, we observe that they agree within their uncertainty bounds except for system 3, which Lenstool estimates as being much higher. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F4\">Figure 4</a> (left) shows the critical curves and caustics that this best-fit Lenstool model produces.</p>\n<p>To determine the quality of the set of 30 lens models, as shown in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T3\">Table 3</a>, we determine the average and standard deviation of the total RMSI, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq33.png\"></span>, and <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup> over all models. In addition, we calculate the RMSI per multiple image system as listed in the second column of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T4\">Table 4</a>, and observe that all systems show an RMSI lower than <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq34.png\"></span>, yielding the overall RMSI of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq35.png\"></span>. Subsequently, we extract the lens properties of Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD2\">2</a>), (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD4\">7</a>), and (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD8\">17</a>) from their convergence and shear maps and list the average and standard deviation in the second column block of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T5\">Table 5</a>.</p>\n<p>We employ a constant mass-to-light ratio for the catalogue of brightest cluster member galaxies, as is usually done; see, for example, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R17\">Meneghetti et al. (2017)</a>. In order to test the influence of a non-constant mass-to-light ratio, we change the default slope for the cut radius of the galaxies in the configuration file of Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#APP2\">B</a> from 4 to 2.5 to reproduce the fundamental plane (see <a name=\"InR5\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R5\">Caminha et al. 2017</a> and references therein). We generate one model by image plane optimisation and employ the <i>bayesMap</i> utility to calculate 30 convergence and shear maps from the MCMC data of this model.</p>\n<p>Compared to the values listed in the second column of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T3\">Table 3</a>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq36.png\"></span>, RMSI = 0.72, and <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup> = 246 indicate that the quality of the model with non-constant mass-to-light ratio is worse. Yet, the estimated redshifts,\n<a name=\"FD20\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq37.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(29)</span></span></p>\n<p>are closer to the ones found in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R27\">Zitrin et al. (2009)</a> and are also in agreement with the photometric measurements within their ranges of uncertainties. The averages and standard deviations of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq38.png\"></span>, <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,1</sub>, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub>, <i>i</i> = 1, ..., 5, according to Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD2\">2</a>), (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD4\">7</a>), and (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD8\">17</a>) are shown in the third column block of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T5\">Table 5</a>.</p>\n<a name=\"T3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/T3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 3</span></a>\n<p>Degrees of freedom (DOF), average logarithmic evidence (<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq83.png\"></span>), RMSI in arcseconds over all image systems, and total <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup> and their standard deviations for all lens models.</p>\n</div></div>\n<a name=\"T4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/T4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 4</span></a>\n<p>Average RMSI and standard deviation in arcseconds per multiple image system of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a>, for the Lenstool model of Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S11\">4.1.2</a> (second column) and the Grale model of Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S14\">4.2.1</a> (third column) obtained from 30 individual lens models.</p>\n</div></div>\n<a name=\"T5\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/T5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 5</span></a>\n<p>Synopsis of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq85.png\"></span>, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub>, <i>i</i> = 1, ..., 5 of multiple image system 1 of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a> obtained by all three approaches.</p>\n</div></div>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S12\"></a>4.1.3 Reconstruction with system 1</h4>\n<p>Reducing the number of strong lensing constraints to system 1 listed in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a>, the free lens model parameters of only one PIEMD large-scale dark matter halo and of the catalogue of the brightest member galaxies can be determined, if we additionally fix the PIEMD cut radius, chosen to be 1000<sup>&#8243;</sup>. Adapting the configuration file in Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#APP2\">B</a> accordingly, we determine the most likely lens model by image plane optimisation, as in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S11\">4.1.2</a> and show its critical curves and caustics in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F4\">Fig. 4</a> (right). We generate 30 of these lens models and list the resulting average values of the quality measures and their standard deviations below the ones for the model of Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S11\">4.1.2</a> in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T3\">Table 3</a>. Analogously, the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq39.png\"></span>, <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,1</sub>, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub>, <i>i</i> = 1, ..., 5, according to Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD2\">2</a>), (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD4\">7</a>), and (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD8\">17</a>) are shown in the fourth column block of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T5\">Table 5</a>.</p>\n<a name=\"F4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4</span></a>\n<p>Lenstool models employing the 85 brightest member galaxies and two large-scale PIEMD\ndark matter halos and all multiple image systems of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a> detailed in\nSect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S11\">4.1.2</a> (<i>left</i>), or only one large-scale PIEMD dark matter halo and system 1\nof <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a> detailed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S12\">4.1.3</a> (<i>right</i>). The critical curves for\n<i>z</i><sub>s</sub> = 1.675\ndetermined by the marching squares algorithm (see Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#APP2\">B</a>) are marked in red, the caustics in\nyellow and the multiple images in blue.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S13\"></a>4.2 Non-parametric reconstruction by Grale</h3>\n<p>Contrary to parametric lens reconstruction techniques like Lenstool, so-called non-parametric or free-form lens reconstruction algorithms make no assumptions about any correlation between the dark and luminous matter distributions. Instead of fitting specific lens models to a given set of multiple image systems and bright cluster member galaxies, they reconstruct the lensing mass distribution in terms of basis functions whose number, location, and parameters are determined by the constraints that the set of multiple image systems provides. For our comparison, we employ Grale by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R13\">Liesenborgs et al. (2006</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R15\">2010</a>), which divides the region of interest into a uniform grid and assigns a Plummer mass profile (<a name=\"InR19\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R19\">Plummer 1911</a>), as basis function to each grid cell. Inspired by the work of <a name=\"InR3\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R3\">Brewer &amp; Lewis (2005)</a>, a genetic algorithm determines the weight for each basis function by maximising the overlap of the back-traced images of all sets of multiple images in the source plane. Subdividing the grid into comparably more massive regions, the lens model is refined iteratively until the desired level of detail is reached, that is, the highest achievable given the strong lensing constraints. Hence, similar to Lenstool, the same multiple-image positions are employed, which set the scale down to which the dark matter distribution is reconstructed.</p>\n<p>Contrary to Lenstool, this method optimises the lens model only in the source plane and no information on the brightest cluster member galaxies is used. Instead, nullspace information is employed as a further constraint, that is, the lens model should not generate images in regions not containing any observed images.</p>\n<p>As goodness-of-fit measure, the overlap of the back-traced multiple images for all sets of multiple images in the source plane is used. Furthermore, we check whether a caustic intersects the back-traced multiple images of system 1 and that the model does not produce any further images for the source of system 1.</p>\n<p>Running the genetic algorithm as further detailed in Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#APP4\">D</a> multiple times produces lens models that differ from one another due to the dependency of the optimisation procedure on its initial conditions and due to the lens model degeneracies in sparsely constrained regions. To obtain the best-fit Grale lens model, we average over all of these lens models. The RMSI between the model-generated multiple images and the observed ones is calculated in the same way as done by Lenstool. For our comparison in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S18\">5</a>, 30 individual models are used to determine the average and the standard deviation of their magnification ratios, ratios of convergences, and reduced shear maps according to Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD2\">2</a>), (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD4\">7</a>), and (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#FD8\">17</a>) at the positions of system 1 in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a>. To be consistent with the model-independent approach and Lenstool, we convert the Grale results from the world coordinate system to the pixel coordinates used by the other methods by interchanging the sign of <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub>, <i>i</i> = 1, ..., 5.</p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S14\"></a>4.2.1 Reconstruction with six multiple-image systems</h4>\n<p>Contrary to Lenstool, Grale cannot solve for the unknown redshifts of the five multiple-image systems without spectroscopic redshift, but requires them as input parameters. As the photometric redshift estimates are subject to high uncertainties and a large scatter between the individual images of one set, we use the well-constrained model-predicted redshifts of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R27\">Zitrin et al. (2009)</a>, listed in the right-most column of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a>. They are in good agreement with the photometric redshifts. The redshifts predicted by our Lenstool models are not employed at this stage in order to keep our lens models independent. After the comparison, we investigate the influence of the Lenstool-predicted redshifts on the Grale modelling in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S21\">5.3</a>.</p>\n<p>As the sources of the multiple image systems lie at different redshifts, the mass-sheet degeneracy should be broken sufficiently by the observations, and therefore the weight of a mass-sheet basis function is determined in addition to the weights of the Plummer basis functions. Running Grale 30 times with these specifications, we obtain the mean values of the lens properties and their standard deviations at the positions of system 1 (see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a>) as listed in the fifth column block of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T5\">Table 5</a>.</p>\n<p>By considering the magnification ratios, ratios of convergences, and reduced shears, any effect due to breaking the mass-sheet degeneracy is divided out again. However, including the mass-sheet component as an overall mass offset is necessary for the genetic algorithm to achieve the good reconstruction quality shown in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T3\">Table 3</a>. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F5\">Figure 5</a> (left) shows the critical curves of the resulting model, analogously to <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F4\">Fig. 4</a>.</p>\n<p>To compare the quality of fit for the Grale models with those of Lenstool, we also list the RMSI for all multiple images in the fourth row of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T3\">Table 3</a> and the RMSI for the individual multiple image systems in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T4\">Table 4</a>. As can be observed, both approaches are able to reconstruct the multiple images with an overall RMSI below 1<sup>&#8243;</sup>, which is also true for the individual systems except system 3.</p>\n<a name=\"F5\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5</span></a>\n<p>Grale models employing all multiple image systems of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a> detailed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S14\">4.2.1</a>(<i>left</i>), and only system 1 of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a> detailed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S15\">4.2.2</a> (<i>right</i>). The critical curves for\n<i>z</i><sub>s</sub> = 1.675\ndetermined by the sign change of the determinant of the magnification matrix are marked in red, the multiple images\nare marked in blue.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S15\"></a>4.2.2 Reconstruction with system 1</h4>\n<p>Next, we reduce the six systems of multiple images used in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S14\">4.2.1</a> to system 1 of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a>. Now, the mass-sheet degeneracy cannot be broken and the additional mass-sheet component introduced in the optimisation process for the Grale model of Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S14\">4.2.1</a> is dropped. Using these specifications and running Grale 30 times, we obtain the results at the positions of system 1 (see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a>) listed in the sixth column block of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T5\">Table 5</a> and shown in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F5\">Fig. 5</a> (right).</p>\n<p>As for the previous Grale model, we also determine the RMSI for system 1 and add it to <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T3\">Table 3</a>. With fewer constraints to meet, the RMSI drops significantly, as expected.</p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S16\"></a>4.2.3 Reconstruction with all reference points of system 1</h4>\n<p>As Grale is able to selectively refine the resolution of the lens model in more massive regions, we also generate a Grale lens model using all reference points of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T2\">Table 2</a>, keeping all other specifications as described in the previous Section, that is, without a mass-sheet basis function. The resulting values for the magnification ratios, ratios of convergences, and reduced shears at the positions of system 1 from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a> are shown in the seventh column block of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T5\">Table 5</a> and in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F6\">Fig. 6</a> (left).</p>\n<p>Due to the increasing number of constraints compared to the Grale model of Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S15\">4.2.2</a>, the RMSI of all reference points, shown in the sixth row of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T3\">Table 3</a>, increases.</p>\n<a name=\"F6\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 6</span></a>\n<p>Grale models employing all reference points of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T2\">Table 2</a> as detailed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S16\">4.2.3</a>\n(<i>left</i>), and including small-scale mass corrections as detailed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S17\">4.2.4</a> (<i>right</i>).The critical curves and\ncaustics are analogous to the ones in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F5\">Fig. 5</a>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S17\"></a>4.2.4 Reconstruction with all reference points of system 1 including small-scale mass corrections</h4>\n<p>For the last Grale model, we use the same configuration as for Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S16\">4.2.3</a>. But before averaging over all models, we employ a 48 &#215; 48 uniform grid to add small-scale mass corrections to each of the 30 individual solutions generated by the genetic algorithm (see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R14\">Liesenborgs et al. 2008</a> for further details). This causes the RMSI to decrease compared to the model of Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S16\">4.2.3</a>, as shown in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T3\">Table 3</a>. In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S18\">5</a>, we analyse whether or not this step introduces unrealistic small-scale dark matter clumps by comparing the local <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq40.png\"></span>, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub>, as listed in the eighth column block of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T5\">Table 5</a>, to the results from the other approaches. Checking for overfitting is necessary, as, for instance, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R20\">Ponente &amp; Diego (2011)</a> discovered that their algorithm generated unphysical dark matter structures in the lensing mass distribution when forced to optimally match the constraints from the multiple images. Thus, they concluded that the ring-like dark matter structure in CL0024 proposed by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R9\">Jee et al. (2007)</a> might be caused by overfitting. To avoid overfitting, we limit the total amount of small-scale mass corrections to 10% of the mass already assigned to the cluster. This procedure is able to reproduce the observed images, as shown in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F7\">Fig. 7</a>, in which we overlay the observed multiple images with the multiple images generated by Grale. The latter are determined by back-projecting the first image of system 1 to the source plane and then mapping this source to the image plane again, using the model discussed in this section. The model-generated images are shown with an offset to the left of the observed ones.</p>\n<p>The critical curves and caustics for this lens model are shown in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F6\">Fig. 6</a> (right).</p>\n<a name=\"F7\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7</span></a>\n<p>Overlay between the observed multiple images of system 1 in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a> (Image credits: NASA, ESA,\nM. J. Jee (Johns Hopkins University)) and the images generated by the Grale model of Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S17\">4.2.4</a> using\nthe back-projected first image as source (for visualisation purposes, the model-generated images are displayed with an\noffset to the left of the observed images).</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S18\"></a>5 Comparison of the approaches</h2>\n<p>The comparison is performed by an automated script after all data have been collected and the evaluation scheme has been defined. As detailed in Sects. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S3\">3</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S8\">4</a>, all results of the model-independent and model-based approaches are summarised in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T5\">Table 5</a>. First, we compare the different lens reconstructions for each approach before we compare the reconstructions among the different approaches. The lens models are of comparable good quality, which can be read off <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T3\">Tables 3</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T4\">4</a>, meaning that effects due to varying quality are negligible.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S19\"></a>5.1 Comparison of model-independent approaches</h3>\n<p>Comparing the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq41.png\"></span>, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub>, <i>i</i> = 1, ..., 5, using four and six reference points, we find that both reconstructions agree within their standard deviations and the confidence level bounds set by the 16th and 84th percentiles (see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F2\">Figs. 2</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F3\">3</a>). This implies that the convergence and shear can still be approximated as constant over the area enclosed by the six reference points. The strong disagreement between the mean values for the second image implies steep changes in the convergence and shear fields in the vicinity of the critical curve. Using the four reference points, the larger standard deviations occur because these four reference points cover a smaller area of the image and are more aligned than all six reference points, which increases the uncertainty in the transformation between the reference points that confines the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq42.png\"></span>, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub>. Evidence supporting this hypothesis can be found in Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#APP5\">E</a>, in which we calculate the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq43.png\"></span>, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub> using four of the six reference points that form a tetragon such that the same area is covered. Hence, the area covered by the reference points and not the number of reference points is decisive for the width of the confidence bounds of the local lens properties.</p>\n<p>Thus, the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq44.png\"></span>, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub> determined from the six reference points are best suited for the comparison to the model-based approaches. The model-independent approach makes the least amount of assumptions about the lensing configuration. The resulting local lens properties therefore set limits on the precision of the local <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq45.png\"></span>-, <i>f</i>-, and <i>g</i>-values obtainable in a purely data-driven way. We assume that the true magnification ratios, ratios of convergences, and reduced shear values lie within these confidence bounds, as supported by the simulations of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R25\">Wagner &amp; Tessore (2018)</a>. Further accuracy tests using realistically simulated lenses are currently under development.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S20\"></a>5.2 Comparison of Lenstool approaches</h3>\n<p>The three Lenstool models agree in 13 out of 18 <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq46.png\"></span>, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub>, <i>i</i> = 1, ...5 within their confidence bounds. Comparing the first two models using all multiple-image systems of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a>, we find that they agree in all parameters within their confidence bounds. The first model with constant mass-to-light ratio for the cluster member galaxies has mostly larger confidence bounds than the second model. Using only system 1 of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a>, we observe larger confidence bounds than when employing all multiple image systems of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a>.</p>\n<p>Given this high degree of agreement, the parametric lens modelling approach yields robust local ratios of convergences and reduced shears, taking into account that the number of constraints from system 1 only suffices to determine the parameters of one large-scale dark matter halo and of the parameters for the smaller-scale dark matter clumps belonging to the brightest member galaxies, while the models employing all six multiple-image systems constrain two large-scale dark matter halos and the parameters of the smaller-scale dark matter clumps underneath the brightest member galaxies. In addition, the low number of parameters to be adjusted (8 when using system 1 and 21 (22, when changing the mass-to-light ratio) when using all six multiple image systems) avoids overfitting to the constraints and the generation of small-scale mass artefacts.</p>\n<p>As the difference in the first two Lenstool models is not significant, we compare both of them to the model-independent approach.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S21\"></a>5.3 Comparison of Grale approaches</h3>\n<p>The Grale models with their many degrees of freedom also have broad confidence bounds. All Grale models yield highly unreliable <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq47.png\"></span>, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub> for <i>i</i> = 2 and 4, for which <i>&#954;</i> &#8776; 1. To investigate the reason for the broad confidence bounds, we generate 100 models by the genetic algorithm using only system 1 of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a> as detailed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S15\">4.2.2</a>. Averaging over <i>n</i><sub>s</sub> = 10, 25, 50, 75, 100 individual models, five different Grale models are obtained. If the size of the confidence bounds is dominated by statistical uncertainties, we expect the standard deviations to shrink when averaging over an increasing number of individual models. Plotting the standard deviations for these five Grale models for each of the multiple images of system 1 in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F8\">Fig. 8</a>, we observe that the deviations do not decrease when averaging over an increasing number of individual models. Hence, the size of the confidence bounds is mainly determined by the variation between the different models fulfilling the same (sparse) constraints set by the multiple images. This hypothesis is supported by the fact that the Grale models using all six reference points (see Sects. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S16\">4.2.3</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S17\">4.2.4</a>) yield tighter confidence bounds on the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq48.png\"></span>, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub> than the models with only one constraint per multiple image. Hence, to obtain the tightest confidence bounds on local lens properties, Grale requires as many constraints as possible in the vicinity of the point where the lens properties are to be determined.</p>\n<p>For the comparison shown in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T5\">Table 5</a>, we employed the redshifts from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R27\">Zitrin et al. (2009)</a> for the Grale model of Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S14\">4.2.1</a> to avoid introducing a bias between the Lenstool and Grale models. After the independent lens model comparison, we now investigate the influence of the Lenstool redshifts on the Grale model. We employ the redshifts determined by Lenstool in the configuration of Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#APP2\">B</a> (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S11\">4.1.2</a>) and rerun the model generation procedure detailed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S14\">4.2.1</a>. The resulting overall RMSI is 1.16&#177; 0.59 and thus worse than for the model of Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S14\">4.2.1</a>. As further detailed by the RMSI for the individual multiple image systems and the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq49.png\"></span>, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub> in Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#APP6\">F</a>, the Lenstool redshifts do mainly increase the size of the confidence bounds compared to the Grale model of Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S14\">4.2.1</a> and the large overlap of their confidence bounds does not hint at significant differences between both models. Thus, the redshifts of additional multiple images used for the Grale lens modelling have a minor impact on the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq50.png\"></span>, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub> at the positions of system 1 of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a>.</p>\n<p>As for the other approaches, all Grale models agree within their confidence bounds. This is expected because, as stated in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R20\">Ponente &amp; Diego (2011)</a>, non-parametric lens modelling approaches can reproduce the multiple images to any accuracy level. Yet, overfitting is prevented in our models by not adding any small-scale mass corrections for the models detailed in Sects. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S14\">4.2.1</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S15\">4.2.2</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S16\">4.2.3</a>. But, as <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T5\">Table 5</a> shows, even adding small-scale mass corrections as detailed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S17\">4.2.4</a>, does not significantly change the resulting <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq51.png\"></span>, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub>, nor the overall smooth shape of the critical curves (see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#F6\">Fig. 6</a>). Thus, we can conclude that local constraints suffice to obtain local lens properties using Grale. The best Grale model is that of Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S17\">4.2.4</a> due to its tightest confidence bounds.</p>\n<a name=\"F8\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-fig8_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 8</span></a>\n<p>Dependency of the size of the confidence bound, that is, the standard deviation of the\n<i>f</i><sub><i>i</i></sub>, <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,1</sub>,\nand <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub>,\n<i>i</i> = 1, ..., 5,\nfor all multiple images of system 1 of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a> determined by the\nGrale model detailed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S15\">4.2.2</a>, on the number of individual models,\n<i>n</i><sub>s</sub>,\ngenerated by the genetic algorithm and averaged over to obtain the final Grale model.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S22\"></a>5.4 Comparison between all approaches</h3>\n<p>All approaches show confidence bounds as large as the ratios of convergences and reduced shear values, except for the Lenstool models generated from six multiple image systems, in which the largest confidence bound is 83% of <i>g</i><sub>4,1</sub> for the model with constant mass-to-light ratio of the brightest member galaxies and 50% of <i>g</i><sub>4,1</sub> for the model with non-constant mass-to-light ratio. Hence, Lenstool yields the most robust local lens properties, also in the vicinity of the critical curve, comparing, for example, the confidence bounds of <i>f</i><sub>2</sub> among the approaches.</p>\n<p>To obtain the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq52.png\"></span>, and <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>,2</sub>, <i>i</i> = 1, ..., 5, with the tightest confidence bounds, Lenstool requires several multiple image systems as constraints, while Grale best uses several reference points from a single resolved multiple image system in the vicinity of the point at which the lens properties are to be retrieved. For the model-independent approach, the area over which the reference points are spread is anticorrelated with the size of the confidence bounds. Hence, the area should be maximised, adhering to the approximation that <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq53.png\"></span>, <i>f</i>, and <i>g</i> are constant.</p>\n<p>We thus find that the three methods require complementary constraints from the multiple images and obtain similar local lens properties with comparable precision.</p>\n<p>Comparing the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq54.png\"></span>-, <i>f</i>-, and <i>g</i>-values of the model-independent approach from six reference points to the respective values obtained by the optimum Lenstool models of Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S11\">4.1.2</a> and the optimum Grale model of Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S17\">4.2.4</a>, we find that for Lenstool, 12 (11, for non-constant mass-to-light ratio) of all 18 <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq55.png\"></span>-, <i>f</i>-, and <i>g</i>-values agree with the values obtained independently from the lens model, within their confidence bounds, and for Grale, the agreement is found in 17 <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq56.png\"></span>-, <i>f</i>- and <i>g</i>-values. Lenstool deviates in <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq57.png\"></span>, (<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq58.png\"></span>), and <i>g</i><sub>5,1</sub>, while Grale deviates in <i>g</i><sub>5,2</sub>.</p>\n<p>As the first Lenstool model with constant mass-to-light ratio agrees to the majority of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17-eq59.png\"></span>-, <i>f</i>- and <i>g</i>-values of the model-independent approach and only deviates in <i>g</i><sub>1,2</sub> and <i>g</i><sub>5,1</sub> from the best Grale model, our results are in agreement with the assumption that light traces mass in CL0024.</p>\n<p>The second Lenstool model with non-constant mass-to-light ratio and tighter confidence bounds disagrees in 8 of the 18 parameters with the best Grale model. Hence, we can conclude that a non-constant mass-to-light ratio for the cluster member galaxies is less consistent with the model-independent approach and the best Grale model, therefore a constant mass-to-light ratio is favoured in CL0024. The best-fit Lenstool model is thus the one using six multiple-image systems and a constant mass-to-light ratio for the brightest member galaxies.</p>\n<p>Comparing all results gained in Sects. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S10\">4.1.1</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S11\">4.1.2</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S14\">4.2.1</a>, and Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#APP6\">F</a>, the question arises whether or not system 3 of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#T1\">Table 1</a> is a real multiple-image system because its RMSI is higher than the ones of the other multiple image systems in most of the lens models, and the redshift predicted by the best-fit Lenstool model is much higher than the one obtained by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#R27\">Zitrin et al. (2009)</a> and their photometric redshift estimates. Furthermore, two authors independently arrive at the result that system 3 is hard to model with Grale and Lenstool. Hence, spectroscopic measurements are required to corroborate or reject the lensing hypothesis for this multiple-image system.</p>\n<p>Finally, we use the results obtained in Sects. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S11\">4.1.2</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/04/aa31932-17/aa31932-17.html#S14\">4.2.1</a> to investigate the merger hypothesis for CL0024.
